questions.text: A 45-year female presented to the opd with complaints of an ulcer over the left leg for 3 months. On examination, left leg edema was present with dilated tortuous veins along the medial aspect of the leg. which of the following statement is incorrect regarding ulcer

options.label: A
options.text: Ulceration can develop with long-standing venous hypertension

options.label: B
options.text: It is associated with alteration in microcirculatory and cutaneous lymphatic anatomy and function

options.label: C
options.text: Most common location of venous ulceration is approximately 5cm proximal to the medial malleolus

questions.correct_answer: C. Most common location of venous ulceration is approximately 5cm proximal to the medial malleolus
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Most common location of venous ulceration is approximately 5cm proximal to the medial malleolus The most common location of venous ulceration is approximately 3cm proximal to medial malleoli referred to gaiter zone Bisgard’s Regime: Limb elevation + Compression stockings + Massage for varicose ulcers The presence of an ankle flare suggests venous hypertension Champagne bottle leg is seen in varicose veins Etiology of ulceration Fibrin cuff theory: High venous pressure → Pericapillary infiltrate → Fibrin → Fibrosis → Cuffs → Diffusion block → Tissue damage White cell trapping: White cell ‘trapping’ → Reactive oxygen species → Free radicals → Tissue damage At present, ambulatory venous hypertension is the only accepted cause of ulceration

Highyeild:

Venous Leg Ulcer Causes : Venous Disease Arterial Ischemic Ulcers Vasculitis Ulcers Traumatic Ulcers Neuropathic Ulcers Neoplastic Ulcers Infections Pathophysiology : Static blood within the superficial veins led to hypoxia, which caused tissue death (stasis ulcers) Clinical Features : Venous leg ulcers characteristically develop in the skin of the gaiter region, the area between the muscles of the calf and the ankle A venous ulcer usually has a gently sloping edge and the floor contains granulation tissue covered by a variable amount of slough and exudate Investigations : Duplex Scan Biopsy (If malignancy suspected) Management : Superficial Venous Ablation Compression Pentoxifylline(increases microvascular perfusion) Horse chestnut seed extract

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Ulceration can develop with long-standing venous hypertension. Option: B. It is associated with alteration in microcirculatory and cutaneous lymphatic anatomy and function. Option: C. The ulcer has a sloping edge.

Extraedge:

Several biological dressings have been developed, including fetal keratinocytes and collagen meshes, which have been shown to improve healing; however, they are not cost-effective for the majority of ulcers. Pinch grafts and ulcer excision with mesh grafting have been shown to provide good early healing with moderate long-term results (50% healed at 5 years). Even in those who have successful ablation or wear their stockings religiously, there is a 20–30% incidence of re-ulceration by 5 years.

questions.text: A 40-year-female presented to the OPD with complaints of swelling left lower limb, on examination dilated tortuous veins were present, edema+, pigmentation+, the abdomen was soft, not distended, doppler showed dilated veins with perforator incompetence with reflux pathology. What is the CEAP classification of this case?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

C4a Ep Ap Pr C4a: pigmentation or eczema Ep: Primary Ap: perforator veins Pr: reflux

Highyeild:

Varicose Veins : Factors affecting prevalence include (Higher Risk) Women > Men Age - Higher in 55-64 age groups BMI and Height Pregnancy Family History Smokers Occupation involving prolonged standing Symptoms : Aching, heaviness, throbbing, burning or bursting over affected areas Telangiectasia (not associated with malleolar fare) and reticular veins Signs : Tortuous dilated veins(Confined to GSV and SSV) Saphena Varix (Large, dilated veins around the SFJ may present as a (usually painless) lump, emergent when standing and disappearing when recumbent) GSV Incompetence - Medial thigh and calf varicosities SSV Incompetence - Posterolateral calf varicosities AAGSV Incompetence - Anterolateral thigh and calf varicosities Investigations : Duplex Scan Management : Compression Endothermal Ablation Endovenous Laser Ablation (EVLA) Radiofrequency Ablation (RFA) Non-endothermal, Non-tumescent ablation Ultrasound -Guided foam sclerotherapy Catheter-directed sclerotherapy and Mechanochemical ablation Endovenous glue Open Surgery Saphenofemoral ligation and Great saphenous stripping Saphenopopliteal junction ligation and small saphenous stripping Adjunctive Surgical techniques Phlebectomy Perforator Ligation

Extraedge:

The adult prevalence of visible varicose veins is between 30%and 50%. Tourniquet tests and the use of hand-held Doppler have now been abandoned. There is good evidence to support the policy of duplex ultrasound scanning for all patients with varicose veins prior to any intervention. Many patients with asymptomatic varicose veins do not progress to develop complications, although a significant proportion do, and there is no clear confirmatory evidence that treating such patients prevents the development of future complications. There has been a range of studies comparing EVLA and RFA. The evidence is generally equivocal, with both treatments having very high efficacy (>95% closure rate), relative advantages and disadvantages. Complications (minor and major) of standard varicose vein surgery are reported in up to 20% of patients who undergo traditional varicose vein surgery. Significant clinical recurrence 5–10 years following varicose vein surgery occurs in 10–35% of patients, but minor/duplex-detected recurrence is much more common, being of order 70%. Open surgery for recurrent varicose veins is associated with a high (40%) complication rate, the most common being lymph leak and wound infection

questions.text: A 45-year- male presented to the OPD with complaints of swelling and ulcer over the left lower limb. On examination, dilated tortuous veins were seen along the posterolateral aspect of the calf. Which of the following superficial axis may be defective?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Short saphenous vein Short saphenous vein courses along the posterolateral aspect of the calf. Hence any dilated vein along this course is attributed to a short saphenous vein.

Highyeild:

Varicose Veins : Factors affecting prevalence include (Higher Risk) Women > Men Age - Higher in 55-64 age groups BMI and Height Pregnancy Family History Smokers Occupation involving prolonged standing Symptoms : Aching, heaviness, throbbing, burning or bursting over affected areas Telangiectasia (not associated with malleolar fare) and reticular veins Signs : Tortuous dilated veins(Confined to GSV and SSV) Saphena Varix(Large, dilated veins around the SFJ may present as a (usually painless) lump, emergent when standing and disappearing when recumbent) GSV Incompetence - Medial thigh and calf varicosities SSV Incompetence - Posterolateral calf varicosities AAGSV Incompetence - Anterolateral thigh and calf varicosities Investigations : Duplex Scan Management : Compression Endothermal Ablation Endovenous Laser Ablation(EVLA) Radiofrequency Ablation(RFA) Non-endothermal, Non-tumescent ablation Ultrasound -Guided foam sclerotherapy Catheter-directed sclerotherapy and Mechanochemical ablation Endovenous glue Open Surgery Saphenofemoral ligation and Great saphenous stripping Saphenopopliteal junction ligation and small saphenous stripping Adjunctive Surgical techniques Phlebectomy Perforator Ligation

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. The distribution of varicosities may indicate which superficial axis is defective, medial thigh and calf varicosities suggest GSV incompetence. Option: C. Anterolateral thigh and calf varicosities may indicate isolated incompetence of ASV.

Extraedge:

The adult prevalence of visible varicose veins is between 30%and 50%. Tourniquet tests and the use of hand-held Doppler have now been abandoned. There is good evidence to support the policy of duplex ultrasound scanning for all patients with varicose veins prior to any intervention. Many patients with asymptomatic varicose veins do not progress to develop complications, although a significant proportion do, and there is no clear confirmatory evidence that treating such patients prevents the development of future complications. There has been a range of studies comparing EVLA and RFA. The evidence is generally equivocal, with both treatments having very high efficacy (>95% closure rate), relative advantages and disadvantages. Complications (minor and major) of standard varicose vein surgery are reported in up to 20% of patients who undergo traditional varicose vein surgery. Significant clinical recurrence 5–10 years following varicose vein surgery occurs in 10–35% of patients, but minor/duplex-detected recurrence is much more common, being of order 70%. Open surgery for recurrent varicose veins is associated with a high (40%) complication rate, the most common being lymph leak and wound infection

questions.text: A 40-year female presented to OPD came to OPD with complaints of swelling right lower limb for 3 months. On examination, dilated tortuous veins are seen along the calf and medial aspect of the thigh. The patient is sent for duplex imaging. Which of the following is correct regarding duplex imaging?

options.label: A
options.text: It is not the best modality to assess for the normal function and presence of venous insufficiency of the lower limb

options.label: B
options.text: Duplex involves the use of A-mode ultrasound and a coupled Doppler probe

options.label: C
options.text: Significant perforator reflux is defined as a diameter of > 3mm and reflux of 300millisecond or longer

options.label: D
options.text: Done with the patient in a standing position or a markedly trunk-elevated position

questions.correct_answer: D. Done with the patient in a standing position or a markedly trunk-elevated position
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Done with the patient in a standing position or a markedly trunk-elevated position In the supine position, even when no flow is present, the valves remain open. Valve closure requires a reversal of flow with a pressure gradient that is higher proximally than distally

Highyeild:

Duplex Imaging Aim : The presence of reflux in the deep and superficial venous system; The exact distribution and extent of reflux in the superficial venous system, including affected junctions and perforators; The presence of an obstruction in the deep venous system; The suitability of the incompetent superficial veins for the different treatments available (based upon diameter, extent, tortuosity, saphena varix) the presence of thrombus within the superficial veins an indication of a pelvic source of reflux or obstruction. Findings : GSV Incompetence - Medial thigh and calf varicosities SSV Incompetence - Posterolateral calf varicosities AAGSV Incompetence - Anterolateral thigh and calf varicosities The B-mode settings (depth, focal zone, overall gain and dynamic gain) should be optimised to ensure that the area of interest is in the centre and occupies the majority of the image and that the lumen of the vein appears as a dark void in the subcutaneous and deep tissues.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. It is the best modality to assess for the normal function and presence of venous insufficiency of the lower limb Option: B. Duplex involves the use of B-mode ultrasound and a coupled Doppler probe Option: C. significant perforator reflux is defined as a diameter of >3.5mm and reflux of 500 milliseconds or longer

questions.text: A 25-year- male came to surgery OPD with complaints of aching pain right lower limb aggravated by standing and relieved by elevation of the limb. On examination, tiny venules were seen. No evidence of significant reflex or deep vein thrombosis on the duplex scan. The surgeon performed an office procedure given in the image. What is a procedure done by the surgeon?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Foam sclerotherapy Foam sclerotherapy involves injecting a mixture of sclerosant and air in a ratio of 1:3 or 1:4 into the vein. only 1 or 2 ml of foam is injected at a time.

Highyeild:

Surgery is indicated for SFJ incompetence Varicose vein surgery is contraindicated in presence of DVT Varicosities with diameter >3 mm: Surgery Varicosities with diameter < 3 mm: Sclerotherapy New Modality - Transilluminated Powered Phlebectomy (TIPP) using TRIVEX TIPP involves an irrigated transilluminator, passed deep to the varicosities, and a powered suction resector, each introduced through a skin incision. On activation, the vein is sucked into the resector under direct vision, morcellated and removed by suction. The Trivex system uses two components. The first instrument illuminates the varicose veins through the skin using advanced fibre optic technology and the vein resector is then guided next to the vein underneath the skin. The suction draws the vein into the tip of the vein resector while a rotating blade effectively removes the leg vein. With this new varicose vein treatment, large clusters of varicose veins can be accurately removed through a minimal number of small incisions and are far more effective than other forms of varicose vein surgery

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Sclerotherapy involves injecting only sclerosant into the vein Option: C. RFA uses an electromagnetic current to create thermal energy Option: D. small flexible glass fibre is inserted into the vein. Laser energy is transmitted down the fibre, and absorption of this radiation results in the vigorous production of thermal energy.

Extraedge:

Sclerotherapy is the original non-endothermal, non-tumescent technique and has been performed for over 100 years. The most widely used method is that of Tessari; this utilises two syringes connected using a three-way tap. Outside of a small number of centres, the efficacy of UGFS is significantly worse than for endothermal ablation, leading to high reintervention rates, and the rates of complications such as phlebitis and pigmentation can be high.

questions.text: A 35-year- female presented to surgery OPD with complaints of swelling and pain for 3 months. On examination, dilated tortuous veins are seen along the medial aspect of the lower limb, with no warmth or tenderness, and no tachycardia. The duplex shows dilated GSV with perforator incompetence. with regards to the anatomy of the great saphenous vein which of the following is true?

options.label: A
options.text: GSV is the longest vein in the body

options.label: B
options.text: GSV passes posterior to medial malleoli and ascends the leg

options.label: C
options.text: GSV is accompanied by sural nerve

options.label: D
options.text: In the groin, it unites with tributaries corresponding to the arterial branches of the common femoral artery, before piercing the cribriform fascia covering the saphenous opening approximately 2cm below and lateral to the pubic tubercle.

questions.correct_answer: A. GSV is the longest vein in the body
questions.explanation:
Solution:

GSV is the longest vein in the body Femoral artery, before piercing the cribriform fascia covering the saphenous opening approximately 2cm below and lateral to the pubic tubercle.

Highyeild:

This is the longest vein in the body and is the most frequently affected by superficial incompetence. The GSV passes anterior to the medial malleolus and ascends the leg accompanied by the saphenous nerve in the superficial tissues medial to the tibia, looping posteriorly at the level of the medial condyle of the femur and continuing in the medial thigh. In the groin, it unites with tributaries corresponding to the arterial branches of the common femoral artery, before piercing the cribriform fascia covering the saphenous opening (approximately 2.5 cm below and lateral to the pubic tubercle, but often somewhat higher) and terminates by draining into the common femoral vein (CFV) at the saphenofemoral junction (SFJ)

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B . GSV passes ANTERIOR to medial malleoli and ascends the leg Option: C . GSV is accompanied by SAPHENOUS nerve Option: D. In the groin, it unites with tributaries corresponding to the arterial branches of the common femoral artery, before piercing the cribriform fascia covering the saphenous opening approximately 2.5cm below and lateral to the pubic tubercle.

Extraedge:

Up to 40% of the adult population in resource-rich countries have diseases of the veins of the leg. As the sole of the foot is often placed under significant pressure, the majority of the venous drainage of the foot is into the dorsal venous arch, running in the subcutaneous tissues over the metatarsal heads.

questions.text: A 30-year- male presents to the surgery OPD with complaints of throbbing pain in the left lower limb. On examination dilated tortuous veins are seen along the lateral and posterior aspects of the leg, no warmth or tenderness is present. The duplex shows dilated small saphenous vein with perforator incompetence. Which of the following is false regarding SSV?

options.label: A
options.text: Originates from the lateral side of the dorsal venous arch

options.label: C
options.text: Its termination commonly occurs by piercing the fascia of the popliteal fossa into popliteal vein

questions.correct_answer: D. The sapheno-popliteal junction is fixed
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The sapheno-popliteal junction is fixed The sapheno-popliteal junction is highly variable and the vein may terminate as low as mid-calf

Highyeild:

The small saphenous vein (SSV) originates from the lateral side of the dorsal venous arch and accompanies the sural nerve as it passes posterior to the lateral malleolus, then upwards in the posterior midline of the leg. In the proximal calf, it is usually found sitting in the groove between the two muscular heads of the gastrocnemius. Its termination commonly occurs by piercing the fascia of the popliteal fossa to drain into the popliteal vein at the saphenopopliteal junction (SPJ). However, this junction is highly variable and the vein may terminate as low as the mid-calf. The SSV may extend cranially beyond the SPJ, in which case it is known as either a cranial extension of the SSV, which terminates by piercing the fascia in the posterior thigh to drain into the deep system or the Giacomini vein, which communicates with the GSV system occasionally joining the GSV at or about the SFJ. In some cases, the SSV does not terminate at or below the popliteal fossa at all but continues on as described above

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A . SSV Originates from the lateral side of the dorsal venous arch Option: B. SSV Accompanies the sural nerve Option: C. SSV termination commonly occurs by piercing the fascia of the popliteal fossa into the popliteal vein

Extraedge:

Up to 40% of the adult population in resource-rich countries have diseases of the veins of the leg. As the sole is often placed under significant pressure, the majority of the venous drainage of the foot is into the dorsal venous arch, running in the subcutaneous tissues over the metatarsal heads.

questions.text: A 40- year- male presented to OPD with complaints of aching pain bilateral leg aggravated by standing relieved by limb elevation. On examination, dilated tortuous veins are seen, and peripheral pulses are normal. Duplex showed perforator incompetence. With regards to the perforators which of the following is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Direct perforator connects a superficial vein to deep veins

options.label: B
options.text: Direct perforator connects a superficial vein to deep veins through a muscular vein

options.label: C
options.text: Blood flows through the perforator from deep veins to superficial veins

questions.correct_answer: A. Direct perforator connects a superficial vein to deep veins
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Direct perforator connects a superficial vein to deep veins

Highyeild:

Perforators Location Below the medial malleolus (Infra-malleolar perforators/ May or Kuster) The medial calf (Cockett’s perforators)- connects the posterior arch and posterior tibial vein Just below the knee (Boyd’s perforators)- connects great saphenous vein and gastrocnemius veins Just above the knee (Dodd’s perforators)- connects a great saphenous and superficial femoral vein At the level of the adductor canal (Hunterian perforators -– connects a great saphenous and superficial femoral vein

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Indirect perforator connect a superficial vein to deep veins through a muscular vein Option: C. Blood flows through the perforator from Superficial veins to deep veins

questions.text: A 40-year- male diagnosed with a varicose vein in the left lower limb, came with complaints of swelling and pain left lower limb. Duplex shows dilated veins with perforator incompetence about 5 and 10cm above medial malleoli. With regards to Cockett’s perforator which of the following statement is true?

options.label: A
options.text: It connects the posterior arch and posterior tibial vein

options.label: B
options.text: It connects the great saphenous vein and gastrocnemius veins

options.label: C
options.text: It connects a great saphenous and superficial femoral vein

questions.correct_answer: A. It connects the posterior arch and posterior tibial vein
questions.explanation:
Solution:

It connects the posterior arch and posterior tibial vein Crockett perforator connects the posterior arch and posterior tibial vein

Highyeild:

Perforators Location Below the medial malleolus (Infra-malleolar perforators/ May or Kuster) The medial calf (Cockett’s perforators)- connects the posterior arch and posterior tibial vein Just below the knee (Boyd’s perforators)- connects great saphenous vein and gastrocnemius veins Just above the knee (Dodd’s perforators)- connects a great saphenous and superficial femoral vein At the level of the adductor canal (Hunterian perforators -– connects a great saphenous and superficial femoral vein

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Just below the knee (Boyd’s perforators)- connects great saphenous vein and gastrocnemius veins Option: C. Just above the knee (Dodd’s perforators)- connects a great saphenous and superficial femoral vein

questions.text: A 50-year- male presents with complaints of aching pain bilateral leg aggravated by standing and relieved by limb elevation. On examination, dilated tortuous veins are seen, and peripheral pulses are normal. The surgeon performs the test shown below. Identify the test being done
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Schwartz Test In a long-standing of varicose veins if a tap is made on the long saphenous varicose veins in the lower part of the leg an impulse is felt at the saphenous opening with the other hand

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Morrissey’s test is also known as the Cough impulse test Option: C. Modified Perthe’s test -Tourniquet is applied around the upper part of the thigh and the patient is asked to walk quickly with a tourniquet in place, Severe crampy pain is suggestive of deep venous obstruction Option: D. Fegan’s test – Palpation to find the fascial defects to locate incompetent perforators
